At that time, the Master
Knocked upon the imperial gates with memorials.
His loyalty burned bright as maple’s vexing flames,
As radiant as stars and constellations.

The nine-fold gates of heaven were locked,
A single gate garrisoned by ten thousand men.
A minor official with a heart for rivers and lakes—
How could his words reach the Son of Heaven?

The traitor Wang Mang indeed usurped the state,
While the loyal and upright met burning and boiling.
The Master changed his surname,
Became a soldier at Wu Market’s gate.

Floating clouds left no trace,
The world willingly called him immortal.
Where lies Penglai Mountain?
Let such matters rest unspoken.

Yet he loved the lofty, pure wind,
Its chill majesty ever renewed.
I come to bow before his portrait,
His old abode’s foundations still standing.

In the Yuanfeng era, a new dawn arose,
The jade registers sealed Shouchun’s blessings.
The ancient pines grow ever more vigorous,
Their trunks bearing the marks of frost’s yearly toll.

Straight to the summit altar I ascend,
Heaven’s wind whips my robes and headscarf.
Carefully reading the inscriptions on the walls,
I delight in Luo Yin’s writings.

Some regretful, blunt words
Stir my spirit to greater heights.
Looking back at those sated with ease,
They seem as fleeting as dust.

**Inscribed at Mei Altar**
*Jiang Zhiqi, Imperial Censor*

Once I served in Jiangxi,
Visiting every sacred trace in Yuzhang.
How could I bear this lingering regret—
That I alone had not come to Mei Immortal’s Altar?

Mei Immortal’s Altar lies in Fengcheng’s bounds,
Where true wind and refreshing qi dwell beyond the world’s dust.
In those years, he served as deputy magistrate in Nanchang,
His talent renowned, though his rank remained modest.

When the Han’s Cheng Emperor saw the state’s discipline crumble,
The Master submitted his remonstrance again and again.
Earlier, Wang Zhang had been promoted to correct the court’s crooked ways,
But his execution—wife and children, allies and kin—brought vengeful satisfaction.

Guilty ministers dared not protest,
And so the realm took his words as warning.
Alas, such speech was perilous indeed!
How fiercely he rebuked the powerful and strong.

Had he merely grazed a favored courtier’s fangs,
A single setback would not have been ruinous.
Yet high ministers and nobles held their tongues,
Pursuing private schemes—no wonder.

The righteous below sighed in sorrow,
Changing his name, working in Wu Market—who knew?
In the Yuanfeng era, imperial decrees honored him,
His old hermitage and cinnabar well’s foundations preserved.

Shouchun’s Perfected One was granted a noble title,
Celebrating his lofty withdrawal from the vulgar world.
Though the Master met no favor in his time,
Today he is honored and commended.

The magistrate’s records praise his loyalty and integrity,
His hidden virtue and obscured brilliance shining boundlessly.

**Inscribed at Mei Mountain**
*Zhang Jingxian, Heavenly Master*

When he served as deputy in Nanchang,
He sent memorials to the northern palace time and again.
Loyal words failed to awaken the lord,
His unyielding integrity shamed him as a subject.

The Han court teemed with omens and calamities,
Yet Wu Gate longed for reclusion.
He hung up his cap, forgetting favor and disgrace,
Covering his face, he left the world’s dust behind.

The rainbow’s arc bent his heroic qi,
The gull’s drought left him at ease.
Ever mindful of the Three Caverns’ secrets,
He bid farewell to the springs of the Nine Rivers.

Choosing a place, he opened his immortal abode,
Gazing at clouds, he trimmed his longevity scarf.
On the dark terrace, he paced beneath autumn’s moon,
In the empty chamber, night congealed his true nature.

No dreams sprouted fragrant grasses,
He nurtured great vitality to extend his years.
Verdant moss exhaled unbroken fragrance,
The azure steed’s nature remained docile.

The Taiye elixir’s blade and mortar were complete,
The Central Yellow’s path renewed.
Wuyi’s fallen horse was in vain,
The dense trees of Yu finally cradled his spirit.

Though his crimson tally once summoned him to court,
His numinous waves still aided the people.
A single stone tablet transmits his old history,
A thousand years of affairs lie within Yan’s precincts.

Auspicious qi births immortal medicines,
Pure wind is entrusted to feathered ones.
The altar preserves the golden tripod’s image,
The well seals the jade-bright ford.

The land adjoins Hongya’s mansion,
The stream flows to the Sword Water’s shore.
Cranes return, clouds stirring,
Dragons rise, stone scales wrinkling.

He awakened to the body as affliction,
His original hope was virtue’s neighbors.
Green mountains do not forget me—
Today, this is heaven’s kinship.

**Two Poems Inscribed at Mei Mountain**
*Fan Renzhong*

His sleeve chilled, he brandished his anti-treason sword,
Yet how could it not avenge the three memorials?
When the deputy of Nanchang stood alone in loyalty,
The Han’s many kings boiled like a hundred cauldrons.

He sought Red Pine as companion and left,
What need had he for fame in the green histories?
I wonder if, after refining the nine-fold elixir,
His indignant spirit spat its essence to the Jade Emperor.

The matter of immortals is distant and vague,
Yet Shouchun’s sacred site endures through the ages.
By the pines, a white crane has hidden for a thousand years,
Beyond the ridges, red sunsets trail through countless evenings.

The rosy chariot plays with shadows in moonlit cold,
The Dipper Altar’s wind chimes ring with night’s fragrance.
The Master need not be called a Perfected One—
He endures as long as heaven and earth.

**Inscribed at Mei Immortal’s Abbey**
*Chen Cangyi*

He advanced loyal words, concealing his name,
This mountain’s spirit enjoys ten thousand years of incense.
Pity those drunk on fame and fortune—
Their blood stains Xianyang, yet they cannot be roused.

**Inscribed at Mei Altar**
*Zuo Shu, Wang Shiyan*

Mei’s deputy’s solitary loyalty shines,
His fragrant name transmitted through the ages.
Though his rank was low, why hide his intent?
A heart upright is itself an immortal.

Daring to admonish, his concern for the times was urgent,
As a subject, he wished his lord to be worthy.
Lingyang was called a fine magistrate,
Facing the Crimson Spring, they stand in opposition.

**Inscribed at Mei Immortal’s Altar**
*Liu Tingwu of Qingjiang*

For centuries, the pure wind of reclusive officials,
Tall pines and slender bamboo fill the altar’s front.
Had the Han emperor heeded his three memorials,
The Master might not have become an immortal.

**Inscribed at Mei Altar**
*Wang Bofan*

The Fire Virtue waned, decline not yet overthrown,
A single memorial from the court’s phoenix cried out first.
Had the lord listened to such loyal counsel,
That traitor Wang’s schemes would not have succeeded.

The immortal’s name fragrantly fills the cosmos,
How many leave a stench to rot the nobles?
Even now, the wind howls, the pines roar in anger,
As if pleading injustice for the Master.

**Staying Overnight at Mei Immortal’s Altar**
*Zhang Guangyang*

I lodge for the night at Mei Altar’s precinct,
The mountain cold, all sounds stilled.
Lacking talent for reclusive office,
I dream of recalling the immortal’s grace.

Stone teeth hold lingering snow,
Pine beards bristle in the fierce wind.
If the smoke of favor could be licked,
I would mount a crane to ask the primordial chaos.

**Inscribed at Mei Altar**
*Zhong Jiu*

Ten thousand pines guard the ridge, towering to the sky,
Within, the Perfected One once dwelled in reclusion.
The well’s chimes still warm with cinnabar’s mercury,
The altar’s height brings the Dipper’s stars near.

Reflecting on Han affairs stirs melancholy,
How vainly men today compose their praises.
I long to follow, yet no path leads there—
Not like Xu’s immortal crane, soaring together.

**Hu Fa**
A speck of loyal liver burns moon-bright,
Yet worldly matters defy the Dao-eye’s gaze.
Riding cloud-cakes to the Dipper’s palace,
Only cliffs and gorges bow to the immortal’s altar.

**Musing While Visiting Mei Altar**
*Linchuan Wu Jiguang*

I stand briefly at the immortal’s altar, embracing the Dipper,
Climbing high, the sky itself seems low.
The pure wind of Nanchang’s reclusive officials lingers—
It awakens those lost in worldly delusions.

**Matching Rhymes on Mei Mountain’s Wall**
*Gu Xu Deng Mengjie*

Ashamed my name and self have fallen to humble garb,
With no means to reach the immortal’s altar.
Though Zi Zhen hid, his fame could not be hidden—
His lofty virtue chills through the ages.

**Inscribed at Mei Mountain**
*Shu Jia Zhao Chazhuang*

I came to this mountain seeking seclusion at Wu Gate,
Grieving that the Han tripod still faces such trials.
If but a single word could turn the celestial ear,
The immortal’s name need not fill the world’s inquiries.

**Inscribed at Mei Altar**
*Cao Xianjia*

Here in Han times, Master Mei refined his elixir,
The ancient altar mottled with moss and lichen.
The eye strains along the crow’s path to distant azure,
While beneath shifting pine shadows, the white sun idles.
Mist veils towers beyond the realm of forms,
Wind carries bells and chimes into mortal ears.
Since his ascent on the Shao melody,
How many times has his flying simurgh returned to these old peaks?

**Zhang Yi of Xinchang**
Returning from memorials, the sun already west,
In the mountains, I swiftly fashioned a robe of creeping fig.
Not for the secrets of golden elixirs did I plan my retreat—
Leaving court, I knew the fiery mandate had shifted.
Wind and dew fill the grove, cicadas shed their skins,
Pines and firs stretch far, a lone crane takes flight.
Burning incense in humble devotion was never my wish—
My loyalty is known to heaven and earth.

Ancient trees, withered vines—how many years have passed?
Those who come here in robes and caps do not do so in vain.
Waves rising from level ground are hard to turn back,
Yet in the mountain’s wind and rain, one sleeps soundly.
If the Dao has spirit, it will find its use in the world,
This heart, unashamed, can reach the heavens.
Fate’s allotment of fame and rank follows my desire—
I will not be driven to serve as a whip-bearer.

**Sending to Yang Yilao of Mei Altar on the Beginning of Spring**
*Fan Taizhong*

The official path wears on, another spring arrives,
I deeply loathe the dusty red of worldly striving.
Unable to untangle endless affairs,
I long recall the carefree, self-possessed man.
Morning draws water from a clay jar to water herbs,
Night dons feathered robes to greet the Perfected.
Beyond things, in the realm of purity and emptiness,
I breathe the pure primordial qi to nurture spirit.

**Inscribed on Mao Qingfu’s Yunyue Tower at Mei Altar**
*Xiao Tailai*

The tower stands at Mei Peak’s highest point,
Day by day drifting with the primordial qi.
The heart of Dao is as joyful as the heart of clouds—
Flying away, flying back, all is freedom.
Gathering the two hundred li of clouds,
Poems and zither windows all turn toward you.
Why delight alone when shared delight is better?
The balustrade lacks only this old man’s share.

**Inscribed on Mei Mountain’s Yunyue Tower**
*Yueshan Zhu Xingfu*

Clad in robes, I ascend the white cloud’s summit,
The gate, entrusted to clouds, opens not idly.
Let it remain in the mountains for self-amusement—
Do not allow a single wisp to leave the peaks.

**Zitang Chen Jie**
White robes and gray dogs—heartless things,
With a flip of the hand, they mourn or rejoice, altering past and present.
I yield to the Daoist, ever carefree,
Watching their rise and fall without concern.

**Houlin Li Yishan**
Clouds, originally without intent—who delights in them?
Since Hua Yang’s departure, few have known.
Wishing to share half a mat, yet no way to arrive,
A single piece flies here in search of poetry.

**Wang Shiyan of Shu**
A lifetime’s livelihood is a body at leisure,
Daily wandering with the white clouds.
Five hundred years later, who knows this taste?
After Hua Mountain, one comes to Mei Mountain.

**Lin Yin Luo Yongzhi**
Once reading Yang’s poem, I knew the lazy clouds,
Now Yunyue is but the cloud’s descendant.
The dragon, without wrath, always returns to its casket,
The crane, fearful, alone guards the gate.
Spring’s mood delights in the company of chanting guests,
A tranquil heart gladly speaks with rustics.
To know clouds are best when leaving the peaks in clear weather—
Beyond the tower, misty rain blurs the scene.

**Chutang Hu Hongzi**
What delights the world
Lies in the bustle of splendor.
Master Mao’s joy
Is white clouds filling green mountains.
The flying tower overlooks vast emptiness,
Ascending, the face ever brightens.
Edges soaring with the clouds,
The heart at ease with the clouds.
The Eight Poles’ Perfected Mei
Rides clouds to and fro.
I, too lazy to leave the peaks,
At times return to sit at the cloud’s gate.
In pure chanting, embracing solitude,
When shall we together find refuge?

**Cui Cizhou**
Immortals favor dwelling in towers,
In heaven, many are jade towers.
Auspicious mists coil in purple and black,
Ever swirling in boundless flow.
The Daoist, descendant of immortals,
Dwells at Mei Mountain’s summit.
The summit soars a hundred feet,
Daily roaming with the clouds.
In silence, observing inner visions,
Cloud qi swirls and floats.
The pavilion embraces the western breeze,
The cold sky gathers the cloud’s shadows.
Leaning on the railing, emotions flow,
Brush and ink thick with cloud and mist.
Inviting guests to discourse on the mysterious,
Fully inhaling the cloud’s rich essence.
No need to divide or question,
Entwined as they may be.
Joyful, all is at ease,
Serene, what more is sought?
Delighted, movement and stillness follow,
Breathing in and out, going and staying as they please.
I long to ride them, knocking at the Great Void,
Together ascending the celestial heights.
Below, pursuing the immortal’s whip,
Simurghs and phoenixes roam boundlessly.
Looking down upon the eight wilds,
Commanding the nine provinces with a wave.
**Zhong Shuo**
Not I who delight in clouds—clouds delight in me,
Clouds and I, both without intent.
Knowing you love hiding in the clouds,
Unwilling to leave the mountains, nowhere to be found.

**Li Junshi**
Without intent, leaving the peaks, the Daoist at leisure,
Body in the void, drifting in the ethereal.
Pity the cloud’s rainbow, longed for by men,
It rolls up the clouds and rain into Mei Mountain.

**Inscribed at Mei Mountain**
*Xue Xiuzhu*

The altar of creeping fig stands high in autumn’s fullness,
The Han’s phoenix pipes and cranes are heard no more.
At dawn’s awakening from a west wind dream,
Half the mortal world is blown into clouds.

*Record of Mei Immortal’s Temple Concluded*

Lacking talent for reclusive office,
I dream of recalling the immortal’s grace.

Stone teeth hold lingering snow,
Pine beards bristle in the fierce wind.
If the smoke of favor could be licked,
I would mount a crane to ask the primordial chaos.

**Inscribed at Mei Altar**
*Zhong Jiu*

Ten thousand pines guard the ridge, towering to the sky,
Within, the Perfected One once dwelled in reclusion.
The well’s chimes still warm with cinnabar’s mercury,
The altar’s height brings the Dipper’s stars near.
